						WEDNESDAY 23 MAY 22:30 BST - BBC TWO


						FROM GAVIN ESLER
					
					Hello,



						I wasn't going to offer a Quote for the Day today - just a health warning. 


A new member of the Newsnight staff, who, to hide his identity, we'll call "Peter C" has sent me a couple of jokes which are so bad they might have been the prototype for the Monty Python joke which resulted in people dying of laughter. 


One of his offerings is at the end of this email. You have been warned. 


In tonight's programme:


The Congo 


We have a powerful film from Fergal Keane about the failure of the UN in the Congo. 


The peacekeeping mission has been powerless to act while a warlord has committed gross human rights abuses and forced tens of thousands of Congolese to leave their homes. 


We track down the warlord and speak to the UN about their inability to intervene.  


Energy


We now have the latest energy white paper. This one argues the case for nuclear power. Does the government really intend to "consult" over the next five months or has it already made up its mind?  


Michael Crick is on the case, and I'll speaking to the Minister in charge. 


McJobs


The fast food chain McDonalds has struggled hard to change its image. No longer as secretive as it once was, McDonalds UK has launched a campaign to change the Oxford English Dictionary definition of the word "McJob".  


"An unstimulating low-paid job with few prospects, especially one created by the expansion of the service sector".


Newsnight has been granted access to McDonalds to talk to staff about how they view their work - and what they think of the "McJob" label, and I've been talking to the company boss in the UK, Steve Easterbrook. You can see the full length interview here.


What do you think of the term "McJob"? Join the debate here. 


And finally... 


"Peter C" sent the following Joke Fit For an Eleven Year Old:


Q: "Why do French people never eat two boiled eggs for breakfast?"


A: "Because in France, one egg is an ouef."


Unless someone sends in something better, Peter C has another offering in store for tomorrow's email. Now please excuse me, I am feeling a little ill and may have to lie down until the programme which is at 10.30 tonight on BBC2. 


Gavin
